article: Hurricane Katrina was one of the most devastating tragedies in American history. Since our _ was given prominent media exposure, we _ thousands of calls per day. I spoke with countless victims who were trying to locate family members lost in the flood. They all needed _ with housing, food and clothing. It took weeks _ federal assistance was available to the majority. Some received none.  Even though we were there to help, the trauma made some callers rude. Some were _ . Some were suicidal . It was hard to stay _ and encouraging. Just at that time, I got a call from Brenda. Brenda was a single woman _ her early fifties with no children. She was all alone and had been living in a crowded _ in Houston for the past month. She said, "I've heard that my house was still _ and at this point, the hardest part of all of this, though, is seeing the _ suffer. The young tend to recover easily, _ many of the elderly have no other resources." Brenda was hit hard but her heart still overflowed with _ for others. "I know that recovery lies ahead," she continued. "I _ that if we were the ones chosen to endure this _ , then God will give us the grace to endure. The _ of our city has given birth to a spirit of unity." "My hope isn't _ on my circumstances," she continued. "My hope is based on my _ to hope. Hope is a choice." The only thing Brenda could _ was her attitude. She made a decision to thrive , not just _ .
